author: {'steamid': '76561197995351187', 'num_games_owned': 832, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1484082405}
review:
Holy shit what a good game.  It's short, but worth every penny of that 10 dollars. The controls are tight, the gunplay is frantic & bloody, and the game is just so much fun.

It feels like you're playing quake, but in 2D.

The game is also hard, but not unfair.  If you have good aim and keep moving, you'll make it through just fine.  I hope they do a sequel or even just add another series of levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988903500', 'num_games_owned': 2136, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1539920200}
review:
The best first person shooter that is not actually a first person shooter that you will ever play.

Butcher is unique among 2d shooters in that it has far more in common with the first person shooters from the 90's like Doom and Quake than it does with something like Contra or Commander Keen. There is minor platforming that takes place in the game but its much subdued in favor of precision aiming and deadly combat. Its not just that either, the level design, the health bar and general hud, the level hub, the end level screen were it display's the number of enemies killed and the secrets you've collected, and especially the industrial and oppresive atmosphere, it all comes together to form this feeling in your mind that your playing a first person shooter masquerading as a 2d one. 

Butcher one ups those 90's shooters in the gore department with its genuinely impressive blood physics system. Blood splatters on to walls and spills on to floors, drips off of platforms onto the ground below, enemies scream and cry out as they slowly die if shot non-fatally, you can chew enemies in half with your weapons splaying their intestines all over the floor, enemies can be drowned, fed to piranhas impaled on hooks crushed and exploded into gibs, popped like cherries, the list goes on and on, it gives it a flair and brutality that accentuates the high difficulty, and this game is HARD son, I remember when I started my first play through on "hard" difficulty (The lowest difficulty btw) when I was in the forest area I thought to myself "shit man how am I even going to beat this game." but as you play and learn the behavior of the enemies and hone your reflexes and improve your aim, you can feel yourself getting better and better until you finally beat it, and then its time to start on the next difficulty level, Its cool to think back to how I was having such trouble with just hard and now I'm on my third play through on Hardest. The key is not to give up or relent, don't let the game win, its like beating your head against a brick wall until it breaks but each time you hit it your blows get stronger and harder, you get better at it. Its a real accomplishment to make a game like this where you feel a sense of progression merely from honing your skills rather than leveling up skills or something like that.

The soundtrack is a really special thing, if I could describe it I would say it resembles a mix between the ambient industrial nine inch nails soundtrack of quake with something more fast and nearly break-beat like. It adds to the oppressive and dark atmosphere of the game extremely well and atmosphere is something that this game already has in spades. 

Probably one of my favorite games of the year and It was just something I bought on whim without even hearing about it before.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014610676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1505422141}
review:
Gran juego de los creadores del legendario Soldat.

Gameplay sólido y excelente presentación. Evoca la época de oro del shareware. Inspirado en juegos como Doom, Quake, Liero, Abuse y -por supuesto- Soldat.

El juego es bastante exigente en cuanto a la dificultad; por ejemplo, en uno de los primeros niveles estás encerrado en una habitación defendiendote de hordas de enemigos mientras una sierra gigante con patas de araña robóticas se mueve por toda la arena.

90% del juego la dificultad es justa y los niveles son cortitos (entre 3 y 5 minutos de duración) por lo que repetir un nivel no se vuelve una tarea tediosa. Internamente la dificultad en los niveles está muy bien balanceada. Todos los niveles tienen un climax, donde el reto se vuelve mas intenso, generando un ritmo muy variado a pesar de la corta duración de los niveles.

A pesar de ser un juego exigente, es muy pero muy corto. Se termina en 3-4 horas y en general la sensación es que el contenido es muy poco o no se termina de explotar. El juego tiene otros retos: varios modos de dificultad, recolectar las calaveras secretas, speedrun, etc. que le agregan cierta rejugabilidad, pero en líneas generales me gustarían mas niveles que exploten al máximo el gameplay y generen situaciones únicas y memorables como el caso de la sierra-araña.

Otro aspecto negativo es propio del formato del juego: Los juegos estilo twin stick que controlan el movimiento con teclado pero apuntan con mouse tienden a ser muy incómodos. Existe la posibilidad de jugar con joystick pero también tiene sus propias contras.

En conclusión, el juego es una compra sólida pero es para un público muy específico: Si creciste jugando shareware en los 90, escuchando Grunge y Post-Industrial, lo súper recomiendo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198265431317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1696118906}
review: Un Doom hecho plataforma, pero aún más sangriento y divertido. Desearía que fuese más "leíble" o pulido el personaje y los enemigos, sin embargo es un excelente y original resultado. Saca sonrisas (y cientos de muertes por su dificultad). Recomendado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080493211', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1644982730}
review:
I felt compelled after about two hours of gameplay to make a review. I don't often make these, but I HAD to clarify something.
Normally, when I see a game comparing itself to other games or reviewers saying that a game is "basically X game" I immediately don't want to buy it. Normally I see it as a really cheap way to sell a game by claiming it's similar to a classic without really being close in any way that matters. It's ALWAYS exaggerated and I feel games almost never deserve the comparison.

I don't hesitate when I say that this game in so many ways really is a two dimensional Doom. I loved the games when I was younger and this really forms a perfect recreation of the feelings I got from Doom. There's secrets, enemies are varied somewhat, weapons feel good and effective, and ammo conservation is a big deal just like it was in Doom. The atmosphere is perfect, the soundtrack is pretty good too. 

If you were a fan of Doom or Quake, and like two dimensional shooters, I can't impress upon you enough how good of a pickup this game will be for you. Get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198251679824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1480431629}
review:
This review will be based on a version of unreleased (but will be in the next patch) Linux one. I will talk about that further on. But first the game play.

THIS GAME IS NO JOKE!

Don't come into this thinking it will be forgiving for the first few levels. Oh no. It doesn't give a shit! You shouldn't be playing this game if you are a total casual. This game takes a lot of skill to master. 

You're movement and crosshair placement must be up to scratch to take on this game (even on hard, the easiest setting!) It will not give you any mercy, it will punish you in anyway it can. If you're not willing to concentrate and be on the ball, I suggest you got and pay MineCraft or solitare. 

The level design, combined with the vareity of enemies and how brutal they are makes for a very entertaining gaming experience. Even getting shot once could hinder the rest of the level for you, and personally thats the way I like it. I don't want to feel patronised for the first few levels, I want it to show me what to expect and what I've got myself in for!

The pixel animation is beautifully done and the response to your input is pretty much 1:1 which makes really really satisfiying when you blast something to kingdom come. Think Hotline Miami but even more satisfying!

I honestly can't get enough of this, I've not played anything close to this in terms of entertainment. And I've NEVER EVER had customer service from any developer, which I will talk about now.



Right. Where to begin. I'm running this game on Linux], and I swore I would be totally honest about my experience with this from the start. 

I first downloaded the game, went straight in and started playing. I started jumping about and thought "Ohh cool, I didnt't realise that it was a low gravity game."

But then I got to the first few enemies and notcied straight away that the controls where really really sluggish and unresponsive, with everything seeming to move slow. So I pressed escape to be greeted with a flashing sign saying "this game is running too slowly, please change the video settings". 

OK fair enough, I lowered resolution. Nothing, Lowered again. Same thing. Went down to the lowest setting and still got the same results. As you can imgaine, I wasn't happy. This system will run CSGO without a hitch, but yet a pixel game if failing. 

So I went on to message the developer (Sebastian) with a letter of disgust, saying something along th lines of " why on earth wont this pixel game work on a high end system running Linux" I think I even asked for a refund.

With in a few minutes I got a reply from Sebastian giving me a few pointers and asking me to enable debug mode to see what FPS I was getting. 

I reply with my reuslts and after a few back and forth emails Sebastian sent me a DRM free version of the game that was an updated version, for me to test. Unfortunately, this version had the same issues.

Within minutes I was sent an email containing 3 versions of the game which he kindly asked me to test. Which I was more than happy to oblige. 

We emailed back and forth with me supplying me results and him narrowing down issues to get the best version working for me. It didn't take long until all issues had been resolved and the game was running perfectly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969807004', 'num_games_owned': 909, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1571587290}
review:
Vou com a boiada, mas com ressalvas: BUTCHER é Doom em 2D. Só que Doom não traz 1/3 da dificuldade encontrada em BUTCHER.

Tão sanguinário quanto Doom, se não mais, é muito viciante, mas não é pra relaxar. BUTCHER oferece um desafio enorme em cada nível e sua propaganda é levada de forma literal, pois o menor nível de dificuldade realmente é o nível difícil. Ainda assim, por mais frustrante que seja, é muito prazeroso de jogar. Há uma boa variedade de inimigos, uma boa diversidade de armas, a dificuldade não se dá apenas pela dificuldade de se matar os inimigos, mas também em achar munição o suficiente. Os inimigos não só possuem uma certa resistência aos tiros como se movimentam tão rapidamente quanto você, dependendo do tipo. 

Apesar de ser pixelado, os efeitos são bem legais e até impressionam, visualmente. Funciona muito bem com controle também, mas isso ainda é dado como um suporte em fase beta e ainda possui um problema ou outro, como, por exemplo, o não reconhecimento de um controle quando jogado via Steam Link (não tenho o Steam Controller, então não tenho como falar se esse problema se estende a ele).

Se gosta de um bom desafio, recomendo que compre, inclusive, com o preço cheio. Se achá-lo com algum desconto, não pense duas vezes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995790140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1495930127}
review:
Scénario minimaliste : vous êtes un robot chargé d'exterminer les vestiges de l'humanité.
Equipé d'un petit arsenal, vous vous baladez de niveau en niveau en tuant tout ce qui bouge.

Disons-le tout de suite, les graphismes de Butcher sont hideux. C'est pixellisé à mort, mais au-delà des questions de budget, on peut se demander si ce n'est pas aussi un parti pris car le jeu est très gore, et même avec des graphismes aussi minimalistes, il arrive à retranscrire beaucoup de violence à l'écran.
Si vous réussissez à franchir le cap graphique, vous pourrez profiter d'un jeu de plateformes intense, punitif, mais plutôt addictif. Vous vous rendrez compte rapidement que la difficulté est relevée, et elle atteint des niveaux effroyables par moments. D'ailleurs le mode le plus facile est "Hard".

Ce jeu me fait penser à une sorte de Teleglitch mélangé à du Risk of Rain pour la vue de côté. Toutefois, on n'est pas dans du Rogue-Like, ici : les niveaux restent les mêmes, et le placement des ennemis et des items ne change jamais. La progression est donc surtout basée sur le par-coeur, la connaissance des obstacles, des différentes salles et des techniques à adopter. Vous passerez votre temps à mourir et à réessayer de passer les mêmes salles comme dans un jeu de plateformes à l'ancienne.

Les corps volent et se déforment sous l'effet des tirs, le sang repeint les murs, on s'énerve un peu, on s'amuse beaucoup, et puis... pouf, c'est fini. Voilà le plus gros reproche qu'on peut faire à ce jeu : il est beaucoup trop COURT. La durée de vie est d'environ 4 heures (prévoir plus si vous avez vraiment du mal) et la fin est vraiment torchée à l'arrache, même si l'enrobage scénaristique n'a aucune importance ici.
Alors certes, il y a ensuite des trésors à récupérer dans les niveaux, on peut recommencer le jeu dans les modes de difficulté plus élevés, il y a des succès à débloquer, mais cela n'empêche que le contenu proposé est plutôt mince, en fin de compte. Je ne sais pas si les développeurs comptent poursuivre leur travail sur ce jeu, mais un éditeur de niveaux à partager sur le workshop serait plutôt le bienvenu pour compenser tout ça, par exemple.

Pour résumer, intense, plaisant mais très court.
Je recommande tout de même pour le fun, mais à privilégier en période de soldes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150572838', 'num_games_owned': 1366, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1483498536}
review:
Olá galera, estou aqui para fazer uma breve análise do Butcher!

Butcher é um jogo em 2D que lembra muito jogo de console, mas numa pegada extremamente hard, e quando eu digo hard é realmente hardcore! Ele é um jogo de Tiro com gráficos pixelados em plataforma, cada tiro errado ou atingido em você vai custar caro, ainda mais se você quer passar de fase, cada fase tem um limite de vidas/armaduras/balas então você realmente tem que saber usa-las e ter dedos para fazer tal feito.
Realmente é um jogo muito divertido e se gosta de jogos difícieis aqui está um!

Eu fiz um vídeo de análise e gameplay do Butcher e convido você a conferir o meu canal:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7LnWtB4pL2I

Abraço da Ovelha! =3

author: {'steamid': '76561198121566759', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1477444928}
review:
I could argue this is the hardest game I have played. Harder than Hyperlight Drifter New Game+, Enter the Gungeon, Titan Souls, Dark Souls 1 -3, Mario the Lost Levels, Dugeon on the Endlesss, and Super Meat Boy. I am serious.

TL;DR: Buy the game if you like challenge. Every aspect of the game is near perfection. Only complaint is that it feels a little too repetitive at times. Just know you will be ass raped numerous times.

I enjoyed it and beat it in 1.5 hours.

9/10. Lots of fun and the controls are spot on. Highly reccommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004802731', 'num_games_owned': 475, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2122, 'last_played': 1500589009}
review:
BUTCHER is a really hard platformer that is a superb experience for any player who likes a difficult challenge and isn't scared of dying brutally.

You WILL die a lot.

To survive you have to be fast, precise and clever. If you're not, you're dead.

This game is a test of skill and mind, if you don't have what it takes to get up for the 20th time and get that level done, then don't play it. Simple.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062813911', 'num_games_owned': 1958, 'num_reviews': 2050, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1477004130}
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

BUTCHER is a game developed and published by Transhuman Design. The game is utterly gory and violent. 

BUTCHER is a fast skill-based sidescroller that gives you a proper challenge. The gameplay and the simple mechanics and tight controls offer a solid violent experience, and mastering your aiming and dodging will be crucial to clearing the tougher difficulties

The unique graphical style is pleasant to watch and the soundtrack complements the atmosphere excellently and the effects make the combat look and feel great!

The only complaint I have which should be fixed in an upcoming update is the controller support. Games like these I prefer playing on an XBOX 360 controller which sadly this game does not support completely as of yet

However, BUTCHER is a gory, violent, action-packed game that everyone who loves challenging games should play!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198132792574', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 319, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1477089411}
review:
BUTCHER is an indie game that's been released in 2016. I don't really have a good intro, so I'm just going to launch right into my points.

BUTCHER is essentially DOOM if DOOM were a 2-D platformer, with a nice variety of guns, lots of diverse enemies, health that goes up to 200% of what you start with, and tons of gore. It's also really hard, but I'll get into that later. The plot is fairly simple: you are some sort of futuristic Terminator (that is to say, a Terminator) who has been sent for whatever reason to the last human colony to render humanity extinct by killing everyone you find as messily as possible. A simple setup, yes, but one with much potential.

The game does a lot of things really well. The weapons each have their niche, and all feel good to use. The enemies are similarly diverse, with each providing their own challenges and having their own weaknesses and quirks. The sound design is almost haunting at times, and everything sounds like it's in pain. The game controls well, which is necessary when things get tense. There are 26 levels in total (some of them entirely built around a single puzzle or theme, which I always enjoy), making the game about as long as it needs to be without drawing things out too much. The gore is stupendous, and is persistent between deaths, allowing one to paint entire levels with blood. The pixel art is some of the best I've ever seen; in scenes set in space, I would occasionally just sit and marvel at how good everthing looked. The art on the gore is similarly high-quality; if you run your chainsaw when there are no enemies around, blood will splatter onto surrounding walls and floors in almost realistic fashion. You can also kick people onto hooks on the end of chains for an ammo-free instakill, which I want in more games now that I know it exists. The gameplay itself is adrenaline-soaked hair-trigger fun, as you run around and try to shoot anything that moves before it takes away a third of your health. It's a wonderful experience.

However, BUTCHER is not without its flaws. The inclusion of fall damage doesn't really make sense in a non-realistic 2-D platformer, and the chainsaw does surprisingly little damage and doesn't really do anything that the kick can't do better. Secrets are hidden throughout levels, but if you die after collecting one you have to get it again, which can be annoying after a while. There are also 5 different worlds, but the first one, the Ironworks, fits best with the gameplay and theme (feverish intensity and angry reds, oranges, and browns) by a wide margin, making the other areas seem like a letdown by comparison. At one point, the fourth world just gives up on its aesthetic and copies the Ironworks because it's so much more fun.

These are minor problems, however, compared with the game's main issue: difficulty. The game is advertised as hard, and it certainly is. I have no problem with a game being hard. However, a difference exists between high difficulty and bullshit, and BUTCHER crosses into bullshit far too often. Difficulty is fair, while bullshit is not. Randomized elements that matter, hazards that a player going through a section for the first time could not predict or avoid, and mandatory loss of health are all bullshitty things to do, and BUTCHER utilizes the second in particular quite often, causing many frustrating moments. This, coupled with the fact that dying means one has to restart the entire level (which isn't bullshit, but still is never a good idea and doesn't make a game harder, just more tedious), means that one can spend hours on a particularly difficult section without any progress, or even a fairly easy section locked behind a much bullshittier one, and that doesn't reflect well on the game at all. 

(I'm not saying that people aren't allowed to make bullshitty games. Go ahead! But when you do, you lose the right to say that your game is for "hardcore gamers," because it's not. Bullshitty games are only for people with way to much time on their hands and/or a high tolerance for frustration, like me.)

BUTCHER has problems, yes, but past those problems is a really, really solid game. The combat works well, the art is excellent, the music's good, the gore is gratuitous, and the achievements are mostly references to 80s action films. If you're willing to put up with some stupid design choices, it's definitely worth a purchase.

TL;DR BLOOD, GRISTLE, AND SWEAT

author: {'steamid': '76561198051650126', 'num_games_owned': 531, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1363, 'last_played': 1670836920}
review:
Fights in [i]BUTCHER[/i] regularly involve being outnumbered by enemies that can deal tons of damage in a single hit (if not kill you outright). Ammo, while plentiful, is just a little bit tighter than what many 2D shooter players are used to. Health and armor pickups are hard earned, and the highest difficulties take them out altogether, demanding a near-perfect playthrough on each level. And when you inevitably get blown into chunks of meat and steel, you're sent back to the start of the level - no checkpoints, no quicksaves. As developers Transhuman Design is quick to remind players, [I]BUTCHER[/I] is hard.

And it's true. [i]BUTCHER[/i]'s dynamics are not the same as typical shooters like [i]Contra[/i], [i]Metal Slug[/i], or even Crack Dot Com's [i]Abuse[/i], [I]BUTCHER[/I]'s closest ancestor. Enemies take aim as soon as they can see you, and their fast bullets and homing rockets require quick reflexes to dodge into and out of cover. The 360 degree mouse aiming demands precision that most 2D shooters don't, giving a playstyle closer to something like [i]Quake[/i] (which also fits the trickjumping and speedrunning that the game offers, along with the oppressively monochrome, ultraviolent atmosphere). Your NES-era shooter skills will come up a bit short for what this game asks for.

But I think it's important to also state that [I]BUTCHER[/I] is, at its core, fair. Enemies warn you when they're about to fire, and they can't target you if you can't see them. If you hit an enemy but don't manage to kill them, they get stunned long enough for you to either finish them off or get behind cover before they shoot back. There is always enough ammo to do your job, and your chainsaw with infinite gas isn't there for nothing. The AI is predictable, the levels are learnable, and the difficulty is absolutely possible.

Interestingly, these mechanics make [I]BUTCHER[/I] feel like a 2D crossbreed of [i]Quake[/i] and [i]Time Crisis[/i], creating a tight and tense game of jumping, ducking, and slaughtering that grabbed me from the moment I filled a man with enough buckshot to make him writhe helplessly on the floor and gurgle on his own blood before slicing into his screaming partner until his intestines roped out of him like a mass of unraveling, dripping meat.

It's fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116588037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1625108644}
review:
This game is like if you took the brutal ideology of DooM, the setup and structure of Quake, made it 2D, and instead of being the lone, deciding human soldier in a galactic battle, you are a lone, invading alien drone, designed and manufactured to eradicate the Inferior human race. Your shotgun does one of three things; A: Misses and surprises the enemy, stunning them, B: Turns them into a smudge on the wall, or C: Eviscerates them, rending their top half from their bottom, having a gooey center of intestines and organs splayed between them. Story is light, theme is dark, gameplay is tight, brutal, heavy and violent. [i]John Romero[/i] approved of this game. I approve of this game.

You can kick them onto meat hooks and there's two achievements for it. If that makes you giddy, buy this game.
People on jetpacks explode into balls of flame when you kill them. If that makes you giddy, buy this game.
You start off with a Chainsaw and a Shotgun. If that makes you giddy, buy this game.
Traps and enemy spawns are well set up, secrets are hidden just right. If that makes you giddy, [i]buy this game.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198131235621', 'num_games_owned': 402, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1190, 'last_played': 1604930210}
review: It's fun, but don't believe the Doom/Quake Comparison for a second- the environments and cutscenes have lots of visual depth, and the game is fun, nu-retro and difficult, but a more apt comparison would be with Hotline Miami- the music is fast paced, the game is fast paced, you die in seconds. Your character in comparison to these environments is tiny- smaller than the original mario- and the enemies are tiny, which is most of the reason you'll die in the first place. After you get used to looking for four grey pixels with one peach colored pixel on top in a vast sea of red, black, grey, etc. (or whatever the case may be later on in the game), difficulty is a matter of whatever setting you're on and whatever strategy you employ. I find it quite fun and fulfilling in terms of the gameplay, and the environments, soundtrack, sound design, gore and everything else is phenominal. I just really wish they had put a dollar or two more into making the characters larger than a baby fly- not even by much, just a few more pixels. But that's a personal thing. Worth the ten bucks if you're into this sorta thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971571062', 'num_games_owned': 3301, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1516937023}
review:
[h1]SANGRE PIXELADA A CUBOS[/h1]
Homenaje brutal a super clasicos como Doom o alien 3 de Snes, con un toque de teleglitch.
Básicamente el juego trata de avanzar a traves de los diferentes niveles, con el unico objetivo de sobrevivir y eliminar a todo el pobre que se nos ponga delante.

Los niveles de dificultad son dificil, mas dificil y el mas dificil. El juego es realmente dificil y las primeras horas es un poco desesperante la cantidad de veces que se llega a morir. Una vez te haces con la mecanica del juego, sigue siendo dificil pero se nota que podemos ir avanzando con algo mas de soltura, utilizando el entorno y sobretodo sincronizando nuestros movimientos con los timings de disparo de los enemigos.

Es un juego que penaliza mucho los errores pudiendo convertir una partida casi perfecta en un desastre, por un pequeño despiste. Esto hace que el juego sea muy muy adictivo.

Empezamos con una motosierra y una escopeta. La munición es bastante limitada. O lo era hasta que por quejas de la gente en los foros han subido bastante el drop. Espero que no en todos los niveles de dificultad.

La motosierra es muy divertida, pero requiere ya de cierta experiencia para poder usarla sin terminar hecho polvo por disparos a quemarropa.

Mas adelante desbloqueamos diferentes armas que se juegan de forma completamente diferente, lo que hace que el juego sea bastante completo en ese sentido.

Los graficos, a pesar de que son muy retro y pixelados, tienen a mi parecer una calidad brutal. Un pixel art y unos efectos de particulas bastante logrados. El juego es muy muy sangriento, aunque creo que se puede suavizar o incluso desactivar en las opciones.

Sonido también muy logrado. Tanto musica como FX.

El juego se desarrolla en zonas de 4 niveles y la verdad es que la ambientacion se ve muy completa y cambia completamente la jugabilidad de una zona a otra. Ya sea añadiendo lava, enemigos mas grandes, maquinas de matar, pirañas, etc..

En resumen, un juego dificil, violento y extremadamente adictivo, que recomiendo 100% y que creo que por lo que vale es imprescindible para los fans del genero.

Por si os sirve de ayuda, os dejo un "First Look" video que he hecho y en el que podreis ver la primera zona, la "Ironworks Facility".  Espero que os guste ;)  

https://youtu.be/Lb4ORRvvLvA

Si os gusta el video, podeis suscribiros a mi canal aqui:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0PmKlXopkymAT1A4tLcsIQ?sub_confirmation=1

Miau

author: {'steamid': '76561198010899600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1531778536}
review:
Pros:
- Fun gameplay
- TONS of gore :D
- Satisfying death animations
- Good music
- Charming pixel graphics

Cons:
- Difficulty can be somewhat overwhelming
- No quicksaving
- No multiplayer
- Weapons have low ammo caps
- Could be better optimized for low-spec systems

Overall:
BUTCHER is a brutally difficult, but fun 2D sidescrolling shooter that should be right up your alley if you enjoy games like Hotline Miami, Postal, Doom, or Soldat. Despite some of my other gripes, this game's only real flaws are its lack of multiplayer and deceptively high system requirements. The latter can probably be ignored if you have a dedicated GPU, but it is something you should be aware of if you're playing on a system with first generation Intel HD graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108789125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1660093225}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016548618', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1476766307}
review:
This game solidifies THD as my favorite indie studio.
Absolutely worth buying at full price. 

Rather short, I finished in 3 hours, but I'm a veteran Megaman player. I'll probably replay it once or twice.


+The sfx and screenshakes are tweaked just right to give it that feeling of power when firing weapons. The responses have the 'feel' of a really well polished game.
- The jump arc is severely funky/awkward to watch with the way each jump is the exact same height for each platform.

- The heavily shaded colors create a specific atmosphere, but I feel like the hues are too bland. Everything in a given level looks the same.
+ The odd blending of everything forces you to play the game by looking for motion instead of images, which is something I've never experienced in a game.

- The blood is very disappointing. It flops about and doesn't spray. Its too dark and blends with the environment. It doesn't feel special at all.

+ Lots of people are complaining about having to restart the level on death, I don't mind that at all. Its a short game, so it causes you to experience each level more. And each replay is much easier as you memorize the spawns.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003785737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1475763096}
review: I wanted to like this game. but it really is too hard :) Muddy visuals, instadeath and no saving make it frustrating rather than satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254312118', 'num_games_owned': 2628, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1476079655}
review:
BUTCHER is a 2D love letter to 90's low-res blood-splattered gameplay. DOOM-like textures? Check. Chainsaws and shotguns? Check. Hardcore difficulty to melt your face off? CHECK (this game out!)

Pros:

+ Throwback graphics and tons of blood
+ Controls tight enough to crush walnuts
+ Creative gore with a surprising amount of detail
+ So challenging, it leaves Dark Souls in the dust

Cons:

- Some enemy balance issues
- (Rarely) a problem auto-switching weapons

Check out my full review here: http://www.keengamer.com/article/14391_butcher-review

author: {'steamid': '76561198120923262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1520107488}
review:
Dark, bloody, pixelly games always appeal to me and I picked up butcher after seeing the trailer. Was very impressed with the gameplay and level design. Gibbing enemies is tremendously satisfying, the weapons having a powerful feel to them a lot like Broforce.

To me Butcher ticks nearly every box, but it's sort of a shame about the high difficulty level. I totally understand that this is intentional, that I suck at the game and that I need to be persistent to improve my skills. Therefore I'm not citing the difficulty as a critisism, but I think I'd be enjoying it a lot more with a 'normal' mode with a bit more health and ammo around.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042369831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1478280038}
review:
Comparisons to Doom are kinda misleading, don't buy Butcher if what you liked best about Doom was its sprawling level design, or if you only enjoyed it on medium difficulty while abusing quick saves. This is closer to more recent games like Hotline Miami or even Super Meat Boy, with very short, brutally hard levels that are meant to be played over and over again until you've mastered them completely. 
It's a great game nonetheless, with satisfying gunplay and some of the most ridiculous gore I've ever seen on screen. It looks lo-fi even by 90's standards but you can see a lot of care went into the details, the volcano level in particular features stunning pixel art.
Also you should know there's a railgun straight out of the Eraser movie.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978012849', 'num_games_owned': 1721, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1477369002}

author: {'steamid': '76561198149892023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1733, 'last_played': 1477286221}
review:
I must say I really fall in love with this game at first sight.
I suppose your playing some kind of terminator (not sure) and your destroying some military facilities in another galaxy, but seriously, you must not care about a good scenario if you want this game, there is nothing but a quick cinematic at the start of the game.
The pixel art is good and the animation correct, the sound and the ambience is fitting perfectly the bloody scene.
The control feel very tight, it's not easy at first to be aware of your crosshair at all time while your jumping and running to dodge bullets. Your in for some frustrating moments. Level are not very long but insanely intense and hard at first. Eventually you will start to understand that you must always be a moving target and must remember where will be the next opponents and what type of weapon will work in this position. At some point, relaying only on reflexes will not work for the average gamer (I'm average I think).
There is some part of the game where you will face waves of ennemies and will need to destroy them so you can proceed to the next area. I felt there was too much of them... You will sadly die a high number of time in these, but the feeling when you will get to the next level is pure heaven.
There is 35 skull hidden (some really well) in the game and four level of difficulty from hard to impossible.

In conclusion, for only 10$ it's a very good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964682472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1558138117}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972532356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1475870133}
review:
A few things that didn't agree with me, gameplay wise was that every stage just gets increasingly longer, so it's more of an endurance round sort of game. That in itself is not bad, but there are a few gripes that compound the annoying factor of the game:

Everything is small. You're a guy made of like, 15 pixels or around there, running around in dark corridors shooting at other 15 pixel sized people. This is the type of "What today's game developers think classic games looked like" kind of character graphics.
The enviroment work is AMAZING, but with that, alot of colors start to blend in, it becomes hard to spot enemies during chaotic moments.
It's hard only because you have such little health, ammo. That's a challenge, that's alright, but that's the only challenge it brings.

I technically bought this on the premise that DOOM gets plastered everywhere on the description of this game. If you're looking for something like Doom, I wouldn't bother with this. It feels like the game is piggy backing off the name.

The game is not BAD, but it's more annoying than challenging to play.
Debating between Devil Daggers and Butcher. I had more fun with Devil Daggers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101863074', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1566830623}
review:
Lets get the bad out first, at worst you will be repetedly doing a level over and over again until there is no incetive to even keep trying. You are just burnt out and the level and shooting senarios get dull and repetitive. I wish that it would tell you when you killed someone, because when I shoot someone with a shot gun and them stumble back and fall down, I think they are dead, but then the seeming less dead enemy gets back up and shoot me in the back. This could be easily fixed by showing a little que like a little skull apearing above their dead bodies or a little "+1 kill" phrase apear next to your character. Ive seen some complaints about how the color pallete is the same throughout the game (which in my opinion is awesome) and because of the red and gray colors it can make seeing an enemy hard, like as if the're camoflaged. I honoestly dont think this is a very big problem, I think it adds to the hardness of the game (and besides once you develop some muscle memory for the game it becomes very easy to spot enemies) Also as a side note this game is f*cking HARD. I mean Super Meat Boy hard, and im playing on the easiest difficulty! I love that the game is hard because once you beat a really tough level you feel like you have mastered the game and feel super acomplished. But the game being really tough to beat may turn some people off.

Ok

Now for the good!

First off, the idea of you being a terminator-robot-killing machine is awesome! You feel like a total badass when you kill a guy, pick up his bullets, kill another guy with those bullets, then walk over to his dead body ad completely mutilate it with your chain saw. The pixel art and the blood and the music completely set the tone! You really feel like you are living in a post apocalyptic world and the design of everthing looks like Doom, The Movie Alien, and Super Meat Boy had a mangled,  hellish, baby. The level design is perfect and is the perfect blend of strategy, difficulty, and guns-blazing rambo style. Ammo and health conservation are extremely important which adds a nice layer of almost survival-ish feel to the game. The shooting and platforming are really smooth and it all seems to flow really nicely.


Overall I would rate BUTCHER, a solid 8.5/10, and a must paly


WISHLIST:

Drop-In Co-op: this would be so much fun to play with your bro on the couch or online through the mic, I highly recommend the devs add online Co-op and local Co-op for up to 4 players.

Online Versus: OMG it would be so fun to be dropped in to map with six other players with a gun of their choice, and battle to the death, or team desthmatch. It would be too much fun.

Level Creator: This game is dying for a level editor, people could create so many amazing levels in the steam workshop. The campaine is already amazing and it would be really nice to have some communtity level to play once you finish (if you even can beat the campain)

If the devs added these things I would rate this game a shining 10/10 its still a must play game, even without these features

author: {'steamid': '76561198040957140', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1502613398}
review:
A lot of people left bad reviews because this game is "too hard", but if you have half a brain in your head hard isn't actually that hard. I was able to beat the game for the first time on hard in about 3 hours. Just start on harder if you want an actual challenge.

The gore is exceptionally well done, it has just the right amount of blood splatter to look good but not overdone. The movement is very responsive, although the speed of the player can feel sluggish at times. The environments and aesthetic remind me of quake and the doom techbase levels. 

And don't play with a controller, just because it's a platformer does not mean a controller is a good idea. The level of speed and precision required to play this game well is incredibly impractical to try and achieve on a controller. You need to be able to snap to targets very quickly and precisely, which is just simply easier to do with a mouse. 

TL;DR: It's a good difficult game with well done gore and a quake aesthetic that you probably shouldn't play with a controller. If you like teleglitch, you might enjoy this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131582058', 'num_games_owned': 476, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1491396364}
review:
Babiis give this game a negative review because it's "too hard".
Look the game is great, especially for the price. Shredding difficulty, awesome pixelated art, stellar soundtrack, and even secret collectibles. And most of all the game is just fun.
A good game to release those pent up aggressions on as well.
If you have decent reflexes, hard mode should take you 2-4 hours to beat, I have yet to start harder runs because I want to collect all the secrets first.
Buy the game!
Only major con I can think of is that I wish there were more boss battles. The final boss is great, and I know it's following the formula of Doom (levels chock full of enemies and a big final boss at the end), but I can't help but wonder what other designs the developers could have used on bosses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013999506', 'num_games_owned': 346, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1475809290}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023325049', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1578877739}
review:
Great old school action platformer, had tons of fun with it in my playthrough. [list]
[*]Can be pretty difficult, but satisfying to get through a level.
 [*]No Checkpoints, health / armor pickups are pretty scarce, and are disabled on higher difficulties.
[*] New weapons are gained as you progress though the game, feel great, and also open up movement options like chainsaw boosting or the classic grenade jump.
[*]Dark, gritty color pallette works well and the music really fit the theme of the game.
[*] Hidden skulls are scattered throughout levels for you to find, unlocking higher difficulties.[/list]

Great game, strongly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962338672', 'num_games_owned': 2216, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1595734731}
review:
TL;DR, 8/10.

This game is metal as fuck.  Extreme difficulty?  Metal as fuck.  Gore, theme, music?  Metal as fuck.  Story?  Setting?  Level design and where you actually go?  Metal as fuck.  Enemies?  Weapons?  Metal as fuck.

One of the best examples of effective pixel art in a long time, very "low rez", yet what everything is and does is quite clear, art style works very well, great example of brutal efficiency.  It just works.

The game is hard as shit, but generally fair.  Enemies get dazed on taking damage, and have a slight delay on their aiming, and they aren't hitscan (caveat, haven't completed the game, thought I'd play on one of the harder difficulties... I was wrong).  However, enemies, even the average grunt, are completely deadly and can kill you in seconds.  Also jetpack guys with chainsaws, these are your puny *victims*... METAL... AS... FUCK

Did you like Doom 2016?  Did you like Crusader: No Remorse?  Did you like...  Do you like action games?  Do you like gory high skill games?  Buy this.  Right now.  Don't wait for a sale, this deserves a cash injection, unless you're in a financial situation where $10 matters, buy this game, support this shit.  Get us more things like this.

100% recommendation for any fans of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198215794560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1555624138}
review: What an awesome game. If you think you might like it you will. But, players be warned! When they say its brutally hard they aren't lying. The easy mode is HARD mode. The enemies do not play. They seek and kill you with purpose. I have to play the game in half hour intervals because my thumbs start to hurt. But its good to truly be challenged once and awhile. Thats the key point. If you like pixel games its great. Awesome graphics, soundtrack is good for what it is. Def. worth the money. Solid game WARNING!! - NOT FOR THE FAINT OF HEART- Oh, also one good thing to know. You can use a PS4 controller on this game. If it seems like its acting weird just exit out of the game and go back into it using the controller from the start and it should work perfect. Thanks Guys/Gals, really good game. J.W.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028183593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1499801955}
review:
Short and Sweet.

Played on the base "Hard" difficulty, it was a good challenge for my decidedly less than twitch reflexes, took about 5 hours which is good for this game I think. The campaign isn't overly long, doesn't overstay its welcome.
I read someone say "this game isn't hard in the traditional sense, I just keep running out of ammo!" (paraphrased there) and I'd like to address it:

I have never run out of ammo in this game or even come close to it, you must've went the "spray and pray" route of aiming if ammo shortage was your main point of difficulty with it and I don't think upping the diff modifies enemy health so...git gud at aiming.

Anyhoo my verdict is: 4/5 would bring on robopocalypse again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050603349', 'num_games_owned': 1088, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1588011239}
review:
[i][b]Detailed review[/b] by Ashes[/i]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Butcher was made and published by Transhuman Design, the same folks that made King Arthur’s Gold and Trench Run. It was released at the 5th of October 2016 and promises to be an extremely hard Doom/Quake inspired, 2D, fast, sidescrolling shooter. In this review I’ll tell you how and if it lives up to the promises along with other things.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Immediately you’ll notice the devs didn’t lie about the resemblance, Butcher truly is what I imagine a 2D Doom to be. It’s brutal, fast and very, very bloody, albeit a bit more tactical than any classic FPS and definitely more challenging than any Quake or Doom game up to date. There are four difficulties, the easiest of which is called hard, of course. 

I got a bit of a Hotline Miami vibe from how the difficulty was structured, for most human-like enemies it would roughly take the same amount of damage to die as it takes you, so unlike corridor shooters where you’d just run and gun, sometimes it’s recommended to stop and actually think about your approach and/or take things slower, it adds a strategic layer of depth. Of course, like in all classic shooters you have enemies which are way bigger and tougher than you, with more impactful guns, but much slower.

One of the things I didn’t like was how long it took to get new guns. For example, you get the best gun in the game near the very end, at the beginning of the last chapter, which doesn’t give you a lot of time to actually enjoy it. Even after beating the game you can’t just go back and start a New Game+ where you have all the things previously unlocked. A simple solution would be to give you less ammo for the better guns, but give them earlier in the game.

Which brings me to another point, after you find a new more powerful gun, you’d all of a sudden get the almost same amount of ammo you get for the starting ones, that isn’t necessarily a complaint though, since ammo in general isn’t exactly much, you might find yourself in a situation where you have no ammo if you forget to manage.

I found the gameplay to be a very good mixture of shooting, platforming and adaptive thinking. Everything feels smooth and just right. Things are very diversified, you'll never get sick of a specific aspect of the game. Most importantly, everything combined makes for an immensely fun experience.

[h1]World, Length and Level Design[/h1]
Let’s start off with the world, there is a very non-existent story as you would probably expect with these sorts of games, however Butcher has a very big emphasis on blood and gore. All of the levels are very atmospheric and stay true to the overall theme. There is an abundance of small details e.g. being able to break mostly any prop, completely mutilate bodies and even a few hidden things which I’ll let you discover for yourself.

As far as levels and level design goes, they aren’t exactly the labyrinths of Doom, but they are definitely more open than your traditional sidescrollers, the inclusion of secrets is nice as well, although most of the time they don’t provide much benefit to the player.
Let’s talk a bit about variety, content and length. For a 10$ game I’d say it holds up quite well, what I mean is, there isn’t exactly an abundance of content, but the things which are present are all done amazingly well. I wish it was longer, had more guns, more levels etc., simply because everything is done superbly well. I can’t really complain given the price, I’ve paid more for much shorter games with severely less content. I really want the devs to consider DLC or even a more expensive sequel with more content. Point is, I want more, and I think you will too.

The overall length of BUTCHER at the standard (Hard) difficulty is between 4-7 hours, depending how fast you learn and how often you die. It’s a very unforgiving game, doesn’t take you much to die and when you do, it restarts the whole level. The number of guns is a bit disappointing, there are a total of 6 guns, but all are drastically different from each other, and you’ll find yourself utilizing all of them depending on the given situation and circumstance.

There will be plenty different enemies you encounter though, from humans to robots and they progressively get tougher, but Butcher doesn’t just throw away the previously encountered ones, instead the game uses the newly introduced as an extra ingredient, which adds a lot of variety gameplay wise and forces you to constantly change your approach, actively encouraging adaptive, on the spot thinking.

[h1]Graphics, Sound and Technical Details[/h1]
BUTCHER sounds and looks exactly like a 90s shooter, I found myself enjoying the soundtrack quite a bit, and graphically it’s very, very pleasing given that you like this type of art style. As I mentioned before, there are a lot of details everywhere, both mechanics wise and graphically. Everything combined contributes to the atmosphere and creates an extremely satisfying experience.

I’ve had absolutely no frame dips even on my potato, the game plays at a constant 60fps even on weaker and/or older systems. I haven’t encountered a single game-breaking glitch, or any sort of glitches, to be honest. Controls on mouse and keyboard are very smooth and responsive, also fully rebindable, for the ones of you which prefer gamepads, there is fully functional support for that as well.

There isn’t an excessive number of options, but all the important things, I can think of, are there. You can toggle between on-off for certain effects and post-processing, there are separate audio sliders for music and game sound and, thankfully, you can adjust several gameplay related options as you see fit.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I was very pleasantly surprised by BUTCHER and enjoyed every minute of it. My main problem is the length and overall amount of content, but given the price I can’t really complain. Everything present in the game is done amazingly well, from weapons to music. Gameplay is fun and brutally challenging. 

The levels all have their own quirky mechanics, and the atmosphere is amazing. I can, without a doubt, recommend this. Depending on how masochistic you are, you could try the harder difficulties and complete the game more than once or twice. Achievements are there for the OCD parts of you as well. I had a complete blast and hope you do as well.

If you like this sort of in-depth detailed reviews please let me know in the comments. Want to check out more similar reviews for other games? Check out the links below!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993503090', 'num_games_owned': 654, 'num_reviews': 216, 'playtime_forever': 2022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1972, 'last_played': 1558791162}
review:
Когда я, наконец, получил Railgun я расхохотался. Он настолько крутой и мощный, что на этом можно было завершать игру, не дожидаясь финального босса и титров. Я был абсолютно счастлив в то мгновение, когда прозвучал рокот выстрела, и реки крови брызнули на стены. К этому моменту я уже привык к мрачной атмосфере, интенсивным схваткам, которые ждут меня на каждом шагу, к ржавой пиксельной картинке и отлично вписывающейся в геймплей музыке. Меня было сложно удивить, ведь, казалось, я уже попробовал всё. Но авторам удалось и это главная вещь, ради которой стоит поиграть в Butcher - она постоянно удивляет. 

С виду простой сайдскроллер, заставляет напрячься, ведь всё зависит только от тебя, не нужно помнить уровень или тайминги, это не поможет. Метко стреляй, быстро соображай и ловко уворачивайся. Butcher не издевается над игроком своей сложностью, а демонстрирует изначальное превосходство, против которого у тебя есть только навык, и когда он появляется игра дарит неописуемую радость. 

Порекомендовать, однако, эту игру могу только опытным воякам, готовым терпеть боль и стиснув зубы мочить вражин, тут есть всё для этого и это стоит каждой потраченной копейки.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038310096', 'num_games_owned': 899, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1475872845}
review:
[h1]The Butcher, a hard story...[/h1]
Im honest, i like it if a game is "challenging" in a way where the game actually makes fun and great to play. Old games are often hard but still fun to play, some are maybe just broken or you dont understand them at all.

The Butcher is not hard in the way i mean, its unfair hard and the problem is its made this way.

[h1]Deep dark mix of grey & red...and a lot pixels...[/h1]
knowing other games from the creators, like king arthur's gold, you actually could see something in those games back then, in the Butcher, its really hard to see what youre actually shooting at, either where you shooting at sometimes. Most enemys have such colors like the background has or you dont see them at all - and if you do its mostly to late. That said, you ending up playing levels over and over and over again which ruins a lot fun.

I mean, i know, it should be one of "those hard" games, maybe like "i wanna be the guy" but at least this game was kinda "fun" (using this word carefully~) wile the butcher is kinda frustrating

- You mostly dont see a enemy before he already hit you or killed you
- Some traps came so fast in a unfair row that the time to react is very hard
- You have only a very limited pack of ammos for EACH weapon.

Said that, im at least somehow glad your beginner weapon is a shotgun coz aiming is also hard, said coz of the very "pixelish" graphic.

I mean, honestly, nostalgie looks better, the Butcher looks on flatscreens like someone tried to create a retro-like looking game but adds some acid effect over it. really, the sprites looks really ugly on big screens nowadays and even games like lemmings where the sprites actually were small look better nowadays on such screens.

[h1]So should you buy it?[/h1]
Honestly, if you like very hard AND unfair games you might enjoy it, for myself i dont. Its not hard in a way you actually enjoy it, its unfair hard since its created that way. it feels like the creators actually tried something original but failed somehow - or they are sadistic...
I just dont recomment it to people who might think the trailer looks "neat", srs, its a mess of grey & red and on big screens it looks like a mess of pixels. Not worth for people who wana "just enjoy a old hard game".

author: {'steamid': '76561197973490373', 'num_games_owned': 660, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1666306577}
review:
QUAKE + Abuse + Terminator

Seems like you play a sadistic T-800 Terminator. Fantastic and properly done pixel art; no sprites suddenly rotating out of the pixel grid. Nasty gore and blood spraying and painting the level. And a very QUAKE+DOOM sounding soundtrack.

It plays much like an aggressive, side-scrolling, Hotline Miami. Death means restarting the whole level. Combat is about reflex, movement, and a good aim. Enemies will quickly drain your health in a shot or two. You'll be swapping weapons mid-air, and kicking enemies around (and into traps) while your weapon cycles.

It requires you to develop a certain level profiency with it before it gets really good. Till then it can be frustrating, as you will be punished for mistakes and wasting ammo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964186466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1567010442}
review:
Very good and solid game. 
The game's presentation is top-notch (the visuals and audio fit together perfectly) and the gameplay is nothing short of perfect. 
The controls are tight, there is a new challenge every level and you get non-stop action and challenge every inch of the way to the end. 

The only downside I can think of, is that this game is very short. You can easily complete the whole game in under 4 hours. If it was any longer, I'd gladly pay more for the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197988437395', 'num_games_owned': 1389, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1640023208}
review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]
"Take 2 parts brutal doom, 1 cup of Hotline Miami, 3 teaspoons crack cocaine and half a pint of severely pissed off badger. Blend until translucent and inject directly into eyesocket"

[b]Actual review:[/b]
In a world where there's too many humans, only one nonhuman can stop all the humans from humaning around. A game with no goal other than to end the human race in a [strike]whimsical[/strike] [b]severly twisted and morally questionable [/b] journey of [strike]love[/strike]  [b]murder[/b], [strike]betrayal[/strike] [b]murder[/b], [strike]heartbreak[/strike] [b]murder[/b], and [strike]self reflection[/strike] [b]more murder[/b]. Unarmed civilians, Armed civilians, Birds, Competing Cyborgs, Fish, Jungle Cats. Nothing can't be stopped with enough murder applied to ensure goal completion.

A fantastic and extremely savage run and gun that gives you swift kicks in the nuts whilst strapping you to the rack and making thoroughly sure you get your s**t absolutely ruined over and over again. It's magical. 

The soundtrack is engineered to invoke maximum rage and this only helps the game in every aspect possible. Excellent variety, clear aspect of what to do and don't and overall an extremely challenging yet more than fair game about the end of the human race.

Devs giving clear feedback, taking themselves not too seriously and overall having amazing support. Updates are virtually guaranteed, so this is added to the list of "this game gets cookies and milk for having a good team behind it"

You will absolutely want to pick this up ! 

[h1]10/10[/h1]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0qBlPa-9v_M
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=02bwfcV2h9A

author: {'steamid': '76561197970365980', 'num_games_owned': 1569, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1475929127}
review:
Theres so much to love about this game, I hate thumbing it down.

The art direction, the sound design, its all a fantastic throwback to the 90s, especially the difficulty. Unfortunetly the difficulty is the where they have completely overdone it.

At a glance I was expecting something with a Doom/Quake vibe and aesthetically it absolutely nails this. Gameplay wise however, it's got far more in common with "I Wanna be the Guy" and similar games. The way each level requires you replay it endlessly to memorise *every* spawn point and cheap death from hidden level traps just isnt all that fun to me. 

Some will relish the challenge I have no doubt, but it just wasnt the game I was hoping for.

Back to Brutal Doom, I guess...

author: {'steamid': '76561197973755794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1586838409}
review:
I find this game particularly interesting because I've just been binging on DOOM I, II, and 4 over the last few weeks. I bought this on a whim not really expecting much other than a fun side-scrolling shoot-em up, but was pleasantly surprised to see a well-designed, fun and fast paced, 2D homage to one of the best games of all time, DOOM. 

Everything from the gritty and dim aesthetics and aggressive sound effects, to the screen-wipe transitions, secrets, and intentionally-dated style of storytelling, BUTCHER offers a very warm and nostalgic, yet totally refreshing take on the shooters of yore. 

The only significant complaint I have is that the character sprites are very small and lack the definitive amount of detail that the environments are coated with. Sometimes enemies are less-than-obvious to spot and occasionally you'll get gibbed by an enemy that somehow snuck up on you. 

Fast paced, intense, and as exciting as its source material, nostalgic yet original, BUTCHER is a game that I find very easy to recommend. With the game selling for $10 or less, you're missing out on a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022193351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1567913986}
review:
Lovely game!

PROS:
-Feels like Doom
-Gameplay is very, very tight
-Impressive AI (but not too smart, sweet spot where the game is still fun)
-Good level design
-Challenge level is perfect for veteran gamers

CONS:
-I played the demo, and it felt more "legible" for lack of a better word. This release makes it much harder to determine what is happening, which makes playing such a fast-paced game needlessly challenging.

SUMMARY:
Well worth the money, buy it if you want a fun, challenging game in the style of Doom/Doom 2!

author: {'steamid': '76561198119835591', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1607582233}
review:
This is kind of like Quake rendered as a 2D platformer. It looks great, which is a good thing, because if it didn't I think many would give up in frustration. It is very tough. But it has a very nice aesthetic, and plays smooth, so you find yourself replaying even if only to die over and over.

I tried to make a Steam Controller config for it, but reverted back to the keyboard and mouse because I tended to play better that way. Looks like they are working on a Xbox controller option, which could work best if it offers a twin-stick style control scheme. I haven't tried it (it's "experimental" at this point) so I can't comment.

I recommend if you like the look and tone of the game, but just know it is difficult.

PS: I tried the Xbox controls, it actually helps, especially with aiming. Better yet, Steam controller using this setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098389641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1665952439}
review:
HOLY SH*T! Dude! That's a hard game ya got there. Alright, let's take a look.


Pros:

-HARD
-satisfying kills
-beautiful explsosions, they really look powerful
-Blood.dude. shooting someone and having thier intestines strewn across the floor is pretty gnarly. blood looks amazing
-environments look great. dark and well designed
-level design is f**king awesome

im not just here to give the game praise. its got bad stuff too.


Cons:

-due to the art style, the characters can be hard to see sometimes
-if you're in a secret passage way, enemies can still see you even though you are hidden
-the platforms you shoot through i sometimes  mistake for solid ground. (it might be just me and i need ot adjust though)
-it's too hard(just kidding)

These guys made King Arthurs Gold so i'm not suprised they did such a good job with this game. check it out, defenitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039470092', 'num_games_owned': 626, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1647226062}
review: Great game in almost all respects.  Graphics are awesome, music is badass, and controls are (for the most part) tight. However, while I don't mind difficulty, replaying the whole level because of one mistake seems is more irritating than compelling. Even hotline miami had checkpoints, and for good reason.  Brutal difficulty is only fun if you have rapid iteration, which is not the case here. Let me be clear, I don't think an easy mode is what they need, just some sort of (even optional) checkpoint system. I love the moment to moment gameplay; I don't love replaying the same sections over an over again just to get to the bit I have trouble with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027635354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1476073765}
review:
I started by getting my ass handed to be a couple 20-50 times I can't really keep track at this point. Then I finally got past the first level. I then got my ass handed to be another bunch of times. I then started to feel like I was turning into a killing machine, I could really feel myself get better at killing dirty humans.

Even though the game kicks your butt if you persevere you can plan and really start to make progress through the levels. I'm on the 4th set of stages now still working my way through it. I'm glad that the game adds new weapons and enemies to deal with as well.

Would recommend, if you are having trouble with the dark graphic try turning up the contrast and turning off the crt shader it helps a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986189491', 'num_games_owned': 1386, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1699298643}
review:
일단 제일 쉬운 난이도가 HARD 입니다. 저 같은 똥손 플레이어는 고통받는 게임입니다. 둠과 같은 학살을 바라고 샀으나 죽창게임이었습니다. 나도 너도 한 방!  주인공이 사이보그라서 짱짱셀줄 알았는데 터미네이터 찍는줄 알았습니다. 

우선 이제 막 출시되어서 그런지 ui가 불편한 점이 조금 보입니다.  그리고 스토리 설명이 거의 없어서 그런지 인간학살의 의미를 모르겠네영.  닥치고 죽여류의 겜은 조금 식상해서 차라리 스토리를 넣어 게이머에게 상상할 수 있는 즐거움을 주면 어떨까하는 아쉬움이 남습니다. 로그라이크성이 짙을줄 알았는데 매 챕터마다 자동저장되고 죽으면 바로 스테이지 재시작이여서 트라이횟수를 늘리며 맵을 외우면 난이도가 대폭 낮아질것 같긴합니다. 

단점 위주의 리뷰를 썼지만 잔인한 겜을 좋아하시고 플랫포머가 취향이시라면 괜찮은 겜임은 분명합니다. 

더 즐겨보고 13일 이전에 리뷰 추가하겠습니당~

________________________________________________________

추가리뷰....

겜이 어렵네영 ㅠㅠ 확잡고 파면 꺨 수 있을것 같긴한데 자꾸 다른겜에 손이 더가게 되네요. 

왠지 번들로 6개월내에 풀릴것 같은 기분이 드네요 둠을 기대했는데 후...


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

개발자가 이지모드 dlc를 무료로 풀었습니다! 이제 터미네이터가 돼서 학살할 수 있을정도로  쉬워졌습니다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166620870', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1475709350}
review:
I really wanted to like this game but I couldn't bring myself to. At first glance, it looks and sounds awesome. I felt like the videos on the store page give a slightly different vibe than the feeling of what you get when playing the game.

I have a few complaints:

[B]The Controls:[/b] The controller layout. Sure, anyone can get used to it and sure it's experimental - but you can't rebind the controls to fit your specific needs. The developers tried ti simplify the controls (pressing up on the joystick makes your character jump... pressing down will make you drop to the next platform under you) but it just makes the game harder as these controls are awkward.

[B]The color palette:[/B] One thing is certain, the developers brag about  the blood and gore, it's hard to see the true beauty of it because everything is too red! So these blood effects and death animations seem to get lost in translation and quite frankly, caused my eyes to strain.

[B]The Camera:[/b] The way the camera  follows the character makes the game feel shakey.

[B]Browser like:[/b] Althoughthe game may have been built from the ground up for Steam, it feels very much like the browser version. The game only takes up 90% of the screen (no matter what resolution) and the animation and gameflow is not perfect.

These are all legit reasons to NOT recommended the game. This is one of those games that are polished and yet unpolished. The game is difficult and these things only made it that much more difficult!

It needs alot of patches before it's in a good place for me to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961881961', 'num_games_owned': 492, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1636558007}
review:
Bought Butcher at Launch and so far I'm not disappointed.

If you like a gritty setting and fast challenging action platforming then you can't go wrong with Butcher.

- A Challenging Platformer -

For the experienced platformer player I recommend starting on the 2nd difficulty (Normal game play with 66.6% health). It can be tricky even in the first stage with limited pickups, ammo and weapons when a couple of well placed hits will turn you into a cloud of metal and blood. If you are the kind of player who enjoyed the Cave Story Ballos end game levels or the risk reward game play of Teleglitch then this is a game for you.

- Nice Design -

The art style is very nice for those that like a low-fi aesthetic but also for fans of dark industrial level design and ultra gore. For a pixelesque game it contains a lot of detail, which really helps adds to the atmosphere. The music is great also and really sets the tone well. Levels structure is like a few classic platformers with a hub world that shows progression through 'episodes' or worlds, each containing 4/5 stages. The stages are mostly linear 'get to the exit', kill the guys, find the secret skulls, trigger some traps, press right bracket "]" to explode like a lemming etc. But there are also hidden paths, which help you get the drop on difficult enemies.


In conclusion, get Butcher! It's only the cost of a couple of beers and certainly more entertaining. 

TLDR: Den outta Den! That's a spicy meatball!

2018 update: Been some updates, still a solid game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198037465337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1584462507}
review:
I was really hyped for this game, played the demo and really loved it. I also clocked thousands of hours on Soldat before from the same developer and loved it. 

Butcher works fine and smooth, weapons are fun to shoot and movement feels alright. Game is hard which I liked about the demo, but unfortunately the graphical style with addition to all effects makes everything impossible to see. You can turn some of the effects off in the Options menu, but it doesn't make it better. 

In red/dark environments it's almost impossible to see where you are, where enemies are, where targeting reticule is. Add environment destruction, blood, glowing lava, screen shakes and effects withwith addition to godly marksmanship skills of the enemies makes the game rather frustrating instead of being just hard. 

It's a shame because if the visuals would be clearer and readible it would be a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020495456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1000, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1494000901}
review:
Kiedy kilka lat temu po raz pierwszy poczułem ciężki klimat Butchera, poczułem się jak gòwniarz skopany po pysku przez zgraję szkolnych gnojkòw. Złosciłem się, płakałem, krzyczałem, chociaż to wszystko było bez sensu. 
Rzeźnik to gra, której trzeba stawić czoła, samodzielnie, bez podpowiedzi, odkrywając mechanikę, sekrety i swoje możliwości. 
Jeżeli zagrywałeś się w klasyki jak Doom czy Quake, ale zamiast do nich wrócić, chciałbyś coś nowego, to nie krępuj się jak dziewica, kup Butchera i daj się ponieść fantazji. 

+ soczysty gameplay
+ pixele
+ litry krwi
+ muzyka
+ odgłosy wrogów
+ poziom trudności 
+ potencjał speedrunnerski

- w niektórych lokacjach panuje zbyt duży chaos, ze względu na ogromną ilość wrogów

9/10 - mała perełka, a ten minus to moje osobiste odczucia, więc nie musi być brany pod uwagę.

https://youtu.be/8eBeLDK_BdI

author: {'steamid': '76561198072992752', 'num_games_owned': 453, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1551684633}
review:
This game is basically Doom 2d, and thats amazing. If you love the classic fast speedy, difficult shoot'em up style of games like Ultimate Doom or Hotline Miami, you will fall in love with this demonic baby.

First of all the graphics are great, simplistic but they get the job done and the gore is as always amazing.
The gameplay is smooth, shoot and moving are practically like walking in real life after a bit and they aren't clunky and slow.
The soundtrack is good but personally I like to listen to some GodFlesh while playing this.
Occasionly some of the maps and their layouts do seem a little annoying and dont give you a lot of options it feels but thats okay.

Overall the game hasn't got any major issues I feel and its pretty solid. If you love a challenge and buckets of blood and guts this is for you.

In the end this game is a solid 8/10.

(I will be editing this reveiw if I find any other things I want to add.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198203407209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 864, 'last_played': 1476041806}
review:
Butcher is very very hard. At first every level will seem nearly impossible, but you'll notice your skills improve the longer you play. I just love the built in natural progression; no upgrades, just you getting better at the game. You really have to put in work to get to a point where you're gliding through levels. That may seem unimaginable at first, but I beat the first two difficulties in just a dozen of hours, and I really suck. You WILL get better the more you play, you just need to be prepared for how brutal it'll be to begin with.

Butcher has some good gory style, but what bugs me about it's presentation is how bland the enviroments are. Aside from the neat jungle bit, the areas all more or less look exactly alike, and even the jungle is barely all that different. Still, Butcher is overall a well put together game if you can get past the initial difficulty curve.
